meanings.definition: The beginning or introductory part of a discourse or composition.
meanings.sent1: The exordium of the book set the stage for the exciting adventure ahead.
meanings.sent2: The professor's exordium captured the attention of the students at the start of the lecture.
meanings.sent3: The exordium of the speech was so captivating that the audience couldn't wait for more.
meanings.sent4: Her exordium was like a bright light in the darkness, guiding us through the rest of the presentation.
meanings.sent5: The exordium painted a vivid picture of what was to come, leaving everyone eager for more.

meanings.sent1: The exordium of the essay provided a clear overview of the main points to be discussed.
meanings.sent2: His exordium was concise yet impactful, setting the tone for the rest of the debate.
meanings.sent3: The exordium of the play was unexpectedly humorous, catching the audience off guard.
meanings.sent4: In her exordium, she compared the project to a puzzle waiting to be solved.
meanings.sent5: The exordium was like a key unlocking the door to a fascinating story.
